title: On the colored Jones polynomials of certain cable of the torus knots

title_detail.value: On the colored Jones polynomials of certain cable of the torus knots

summary:
In this paper, we study the asymptotic behavior of the colored Jones
polynomials evaluated at roots of unity for a special class of knots. We show
that certain limit is zero as predicted by the volume conjecture.

summary_detail.value:
In this paper, we study the asymptotic behavior of the colored Jones
polynomials evaluated at roots of unity for a special class of knots. We show
that certain limit is zero as predicted by the volume conjecture.

author: Qihou Liu
fulltext:
arXiv:0807.4780v1 [math.GT] 30 Jul 2008

ON THE COLORED JONES POLYNOMIALS
OF CERTAIN CABLE OF THE TORUS KNOTS
QIHOU LIU

Abstract. In this paper, we study the asymptotic behavior of the
colored Jones polynomials evaluated at roots of unity for a special
class of knots. We show that certain limit is zero as predicted by
the volume conjecture.

1. Introduction
In[3], Kashaev obtained an explicit expansion of the colored Jones
polynomials evaluated at roots of unity for the torus knots. As a consequence, it is shown that the volume conjecture holds for such knots,
-that is:
 σ

JN (A,T )
log

)

=0
N →∞
N
Using a formula from Morton[9], one can show that the quantity
inside log function is bounded from above by a polynomial of N. To
complete the argument, however, one need to bound this quantity from
below. In a recent preprint by Roland van der Veen [11], the author
claims a proof for those knots with volume zero. An upper bound is
obtained. We still need to see how the lower bound would be treated.
In this paper, we extend Kashaev's method to give an expansion of
colored Jones polynomials for certain cable of the torus knots. Then
we show that the above limit is zero based on this estimation. The
whole paper is organized as follows. The next two sections contain
some definitions and a formula we shall use-without proof. Section 4
states the main theorem and its corollary. In section 5 and 6 we carry
out evaluation of the polynomials and some estimations. The proof of
the main theorem is finished in section 7.
Date: July 25,2008.
1

 2

QIHOU LIU

2. Basic definitions and notations
In this section we list some basic definitions and notations. For
details, see Lickorish's book[4] and [2]. For a survey of the skein theory
and some generalization, see[5].
Given a compact oriented 3-manifold M, and a ring of coefficients
R = Z[A, A−1 ], define a R − module by
SS(M) = the f ree module generated by f ramed links in M
where two framed links isotopic to each other are regarded as the same
one.
Definition 1. The skein module associated to M is
S(M) = SS(M)/the Kauf f man skein relations
The skein relations are the following:

2

−2

= (−A − A )

=

A

+ A

−1

2.1. Examples. We list two examples here.
2.1.1. The skein module of S 3 . The skein module of S 3 is just equal
to Z[A, A−1 ].- Given a planar diagram of a famed link L in S 3 , by
applying the skein relation repeatedly to resolve the crossings and remove the unknots, L can be reduced to the empty link multiplied by
a Laurent polynomial of A. In this way, we associate a polynomial
to each framed link in S 3 . Multiplied by a normalization factor, we
will get a polynomial which is independent of the framing of L. Up to
change of variables, this is just the Jones polynomial of L.
2.1.2. The skein module of D × S 1 . The situation in the solid torus is
a bit different. Using the skein relations, we can not reduce every link
to the empty one. Certain essential links remain. And S(D × S 1 ) is
a free R − module generated by those elements represented by parallel

 CABLE OF THE TORUS KNOTS

3

strings along the core of the solid torus, see the pictures below.

2.1.3. The algebra structure of S(D × S 1 ) and an alternative basis.
The skein module of the standard solid torus D × S 1 has an algebra
structure. Let's define the multiplication now. Fix a curve on ∂(D ×
S 1 ), say {1} × S 1 - here we identify D with the unit disk in the
complex plane, call it C+ . Pick another curve on ∂(D × S 1 ) parallel
to C+ , say {−1} × S 1 , call it C− . Pick two copies of D × S 1 , glue
the first one to the second one by gluing a neighborhood of C+ in the
boundary from the first copy to a neighborhood of C− in the boundary
from the second copy, we have a new solid torus. The multiplication
of two elements from S(D × S 1 ) is obtained by juxtaposition of two
skeins. See the picture below.

With this multiplication, S(D×S 1 ) become a commutative R−algebra.
It is isomorphic to R[z1 ], where z1 is one of the basis elements described
above. We also have zn = z1n .
Then we define the following elements {en |n integers} of S(D × S 1 )
by e0 = 1, e1 = z1 and z1 en = en−1 + en+1 . These relations determine
en for n ≥ 0 as well as those en where n < 0. And the set {en |n ≥ 0}
is a basis of S(D × S 1 ), since each en is a monic polynomial of z1

 4

QIHOU LIU

with degree n. We also have the relation en = −e−n−2 . -This can be
checked by induction.
Next let's describe the multiplication using this new basis. First let's
introduce a new definition.
Definition 2. A triple of nonnegative integers (l, m, n) is called admissible if l + m + n is even and (l, m, n) satisfies the triangle inequality,
that is
|m − n| ≤ l ≤ m + n
Then for m, n nonnegative, we have

(l,m,n) admissible

This can also be checked by induction on n.
2.2. The multilinear bracket. Given an framed link L in M with
components K1 , K2 , ...Km , say Kj with framing σj , we can construct
multilinear bracket h∗, ∗, ..., ∗iL in S(M) as following:
the framing σj of Kj determines a diffeomorphism
τj : D × S 1 → a tubular neighbourhood of Kj
view τj as a map D × S 1 → M, it induces a homomorphism
(τj )∗ : S(D × S 1 ) → S(M)
these (τj )∗ combine together to give us a multi-linear map
τ∗ : S(D × S 1 ) × S(D × S 1 ) × ... × S(D × S 1 ) → S(M)
where the product contains m factors. Define hx1 , x2 , ..., xm iL to be
τ∗ (x1 , x2 , ..., xm ).
If each component L is colored by some integer, say Kj is colored by
nj , then the colored framed link L give us an element in S(M), that is
hen1 , en2 , ..., enm iL .
Remark 1. If we change the framing of certain components of L, while
keep the colors unchanged, say σ1 is changed to σ1 + b, then
2

hen1 , en2 , ..., enm iL′ = (−1)bn1 Ab(n1 +2n1 ) hen1 , en2 , ..., enm iL
where L′ is the same link as L with changed framings.

 CABLE OF THE TORUS KNOTS

5

2.2.1. Examples. If K is a knot in S 3 with framing σ, the n-th colored
Jones polynomial of K –Jnσ (A, K)– is defined to be hen iK ,which is an
element of S(S 3 ). Since S(S 3 ) is just equal to Z[A, A−1 ], this element
is actually a Laurent polynomial of A. In particular,
hen iU = (−1)n [n + 1]
where U is the unknot with framing zero, and [m] =

A2m −A−2m
.
A2 −A−2

2.2.2. The framing convention. Since the linking number of two knots
in oriented S 3 is defined, the framing of a knot in S 3 can be specified
by an integer- the linking number. So for a knot K in S 3 , we can
also say K has framing n, where n is some integer. Among all the
framings, zero framing is a special one. If K has framing 0, we will
write Jn (A, K) for the colored Jones polynomial instead of Jn0 (A, K).
For an arbitrary M, the linking number is not defined, thus the
framing of a knot K in M can not be specified by an integer. However,
under circumstances it is still possible. For example, M is the solid
torus D × S 1 with a chosen curve C+ - {1} × S 1 - on its boundary.
Embed it into S 3 , then a framed knot K in M is mapped to a framed
knot in S 3 , and its framing corresponds to an integer. In general the
corresponding integer will change if we change the embedding. However
if we embed D × S 1 into S 3 in such a way that C+ has linking number
zero with the core of the solid torus after the embedding, then the
corresponding integer remains the same. So we will say a knot K in
D × S 1 has framing n for some integer n in the sense that the knot is
viewed as a knot in S 3 through such kind of embedding of D × S 1 into
S 3.
3. A cable expansion formula
In this section, we will follow the framing convention stated previously.
Let M be the standard solid torus D × S 1 , our link L consists of two
components: K1 is given by
(ρ exp(iqθ), exp(ipθ))|0≤θ≤2π
where p, q are coprime integers, 0 < ρ < 1; K2 is just the core of the
solid torus
(0, exp(iθ))|0≤θ≤2π
Here we identify D with the unit disk in the complex plane and S 1
with the unit circle.
Framings of both components can be described using integers. Fix
the framing of K2 to be 0. The framing σ of K1 corresponds to some

 6

QIHOU LIU

integer, we also denote it by σ. Color K2 by a nonnegative integer s,
color K1 by a nonnegative integer N. Then heN , es iL is some element
of S(D × S 1 ), denote it by TσN (p, q; s).
As an element of S(D × S 1 ), TσN (p, q; s) can be expressed as a linear
combination of the basis elements {el }|l≥0 . The coefficients before el is
denoted by gσl (p, q; s), i.e. we have

formula for these coefficients are the following:

Next we will consider the asymptotic expansion of each of the four
terms and show that they don't cancel each other.
6.1. The double summation. First consider the double summation.
One can check that θ(ξm , ηn ) = st πi, where s, t are integers, depending
on p1 , q1 , p2 , q2 and k, l. So FN (ξm , ηn ) depends on N periodically, and
there is a common period of them, which is independent of N.
So the double summation is a quantity depend on N periodically.

QIHOU LIU

Up to now, we have obtained asymptotic expansions of the four parts
of IN , hence an asymptotic expansions of IN itself.
7. Proof of theorem 3
Proof of Theorem 3. Now back to IN , it decomposes into four parts -a
double integral, two summation of integrals and a double summation.
By expanding each of the four parts, we have shown that (A) is true.
The only question remains is whether there is a non-vanishing term.
Note that those terms with positive integer exponents come from IN′
only, and there is a nonzero term in the expansion of IN′ .-Actually
the first term in this expansion is nonzero as one can check with the
help of the lemma below:
Lemma 4. Let α be a complex number, Reα > 0, f (x1 , x2 ) is a positive
definite quadratic form of x1 , x2 ,
